Lignin, a complex phenolic biopolymer, is currently an inadequately utilized component of lignocellulosic biomass because the aromatic structure and high chemical stability of lignin make its extraction from biomass challenging. Oxidative fractionation and depolymerization, particularly with the aid of metal catalysts, holds significant potential for transforming lignin into high-value chemicals, including phenolics, aldehydes, and carboxylic acids. This review offers a comprehensive overview of recent progress in the oxidative valorization of lignin, focusing on proposed catalytic systems, solvent selection, the oxidant efficiency, and depolymerization mechanisms. This paper uniquely adopts a comparative approach, highlighting the influence of solvent polarity and reactivity, catalyst metal type, and support materials on product distribution. Besides critically analyzing the role of catalysts, catalyst supports, and reaction conditions in enhancing the selectivity and yield of target products, integrated approaches, such as one-pot catalytic processes and solvent-modulated fractionation techniques, which can improve the efficiency and economic feasibility of lignin processing are discussed in this review. Moreover, this review emphasizes recent advances in redox-active catalyst design in solvent system engineering. Despite significant progress, certain challenges, such as poor catalyst stability, process scalability, and selectivity for the desired products, persist in lignin extraction. To address these issues, future research should prioritize advanced catalytic models, optimized processes, and the development of environmentally benign and cost-effective technologies that can unlock the potential of lignin as a sustainable feedstock for the production of bio-based chemicals. This abundant and renewable resource can provide sustainable alternatives to fossil fuels. Lignocellulosic biomass, derived mainly from agro residues, forestry waste, and dedicated biomass crops, contains cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin. Cellulose and hemicellulose are used directly in paper manufacturing and bioethanol production [1], while lignin, a heterogeneous phenolic polymer that imparts rigidity to plant cell walls and comprises 15–40 % of the dry weight of most plants, is not currently used in applications related to high-value products. However, the cross-linked three-dimensional phenolic polymer lignin plays a crucial role in providing strength to the structural assembly of plants and imparts them impermeability and resistance toward microbial attack and oxidative stress [2]. Moreover, challenges in the efficient breakdown and conversion of lignin into high-value products make lignin valorization difficult. Lignin depolymerization frequently results in low product selectivity and complex mixtures, resulting in complicated downstream separation. Additionally, the inherent chemical stability of lignin restricts its reactivity, and catalytic systems are rendered inefficient by deactivation and low-efficiency issues. Moreover, high processing costs, restricted market demand for lignin-derived products, and environmental issues significantly impede the commercial viability of lignin processing [3]. Furthermore, the existence of diverse functional groups and connections within the lignin structure, including ethers, esters, and C–C bonds, necessitates distinct reaction conditions for selective bond cleavage, and the limited solubility of lignin in prevalent organic solvents and its propensity to generate resistant char during thermochemical procedures exacerbate the challenges in lignin valorization [4]. To address these challenges and reveal the renewable potential of lignin as a source of valuable aromatic compounds, thermochemical methods for lignin fractionation and conversion have been extensively investigated. To date, various thermochemical methods, such as oxidation, thermal cracking, catalytic reduction, and enzymatic degradation, have been investigated for the fractionation and depolymerization of lignin, i.e., to decompose the complicated structure of lignin and transform it into valuable chemicals [5]. These approaches aim to selectively cleave bonds within the lignin structure to generate valuable aromatic compounds. Cracking and reduction primarily aim to depolymerize lignin and produce phenolic monomers, which are crucial precursors for fuel and chemical synthesis, while oxidation reactions aim to produce complex aromatic molecules, including phenolics, aldehydes, and carboxylic acids, for utilization in the pharmaceutical, polymer, and fragrance sectors [6]. These changes, which are frequently aided by catalysts, elevated temperatures, or oxidizing agents, generally entail the cleavage of etheric or CO and CC bonds within the complex structure of lignin. Among the various lignin valorization strategies, oxidative fractionation and depolymerization stand out for their ability to both solubilize lignin and selectively produce oxygenated aromatics under relatively mild, environmentally benign conditions. Unlike reductive or pyrolytic methods, oxidative routes offer greater control over product selectivity, compatibility with one-pot processing, and alignment with green chemistry principles. Their operability with air, O₂, or green oxidants, combined with advances in redox-active catalysts and solvent systems, make these routes particularly promising for scalable and sustainable lignin conversion. Accordingly, this review focuses on recent developments in oxidative lignin valorization as a viable path toward platform chemical production within a circular bioeconomy framework. While several reviews have focused on the general mechanisms and catalysts for lignin depolymerization [7–10], few have offered a side-by-side comparison of solvent classes, economic vs. precious metal systems, and the support-material effects on reaction outcomes. This review fills that gap by systematically comparing these factors and contextualizing them within recent experimental innovations (2015–2024). Moreover, this study highlights current frontier research in oxidative fractionation and depolymerization strategies for the sustainable valorization of lignin. These methods offer significant advantages, including the selective bond cleavage of the complex polymeric structure of lignin, leading to the formation of value-added aromatics with various industrial applications. Latest advancements in these techniques are discussed to highlight their ability to efficiently produce fine chemicals and bio-based materials, formulate strategies to address their limitations, and underscore their potential to contribute toward the development of a bio-circular green economy. 2 Lignin structure and challenges in valorization The utilization of lignin, an aromatic macromolecule that reinforces the cell walls of plants, is significantly hindered by its complicated structure (Fig. 1 ). Typical lignin consists of three main building blocks of monolignol units, namely, sinapyl (S-unit), coniferyl (G-unit), and p-coumaryl (H-unit), which are connected to a network via CO and CC linkages. Etheric bonds in lignin, i.e., β–O–4 and α–O–4 links, comprise relatively weak linkages; the strong CC bonds in the system, such as 5–5 linkages, show significant resistance to cleavage. As the complex and densely interwoven nature of lignin hinders its utilization, high-molecular-weight lignin must be converted to a relatively low molecular weight species prior to utilization in specific applications [11]. Moreover, the various functional groups in lignin, such as the methoxy, hydroxyl, and carbonyl groups, participate in a wide range of chemical reactions and interactions, yielding diverse chemical outputs, thereby complicating the development of efficient lignin valorization processes [6]. In addition, the different compositions and structural variations of lignin among different plant groups make lignin valorization challenging. Lignin from different plant groups contain different proportions and distributions of the three main lignin monomers–sinapyl or syringyl (S-unit), coniferyl or guaiacyl (G-unit), and p-coumaryl or hydroxyphenyl (H-unit). Softwood typically contains lignin that predominantly comprises guaiacyl units, whereas the lignin from hardwood contains varying ratios of syringyl and guaiacyl units. Grass lignin shows a relatively balanced composition with similar S/G/H ratios. The heterogeneity of the lignin structure affects its depolymerization efficiency, product selectivity, and catalyst efficiency. The high S-unit concentration in hardwood facilitates depolymerization because of a low number of C–C linkages, whereas the G-rich lignin in softwoods exhibits high recalcitrance [12]. Among the several major challenges complicating efficient lignin valorization, one of the most fundamental is the non-uniformity of the lignin structure, even for lignin samples derived from the same biomass source. Extraction processes, such as Kraft, organosolv, and soda pulping, alter the native structure of lignin, introducing new bonds and defects that make the system more resistant toward controlled depolymerization. This inconsistency hampers process standardization and reduces catalyst performance across feedstocks. Second, lignin depolymerization often leads to repolymerization or condensation reactions due to the high reactivity of intermediate radicals and aldehydes, especially under thermal or oxidative conditions. These side reactions form unreactive, high-molecular-weight species that reduce product yields and clog reactor systems. Third, the limited solubility of lignin in conventional solvents restricts its availability to catalytic surfaces, necessitating the use of specialized solvents or pre-treatment strategies that raise environmental and economic concerns. Therefore, optimizing the solvent polarity, hydrogen-bonding capacity, and pH sensitivity is critical for dissolving lignin effectively without degrading valuable functionalities. Despite the limited development of robust catalysts and biocatalysts that can selectively convert lignin into high-value products, several studies have attempted to develop efficient downstream depolymerization processes for lignin valorization, focusing primarily on the application of heat and metal catalysts for the decomposition of lignin macromolecules [13]. The presence of a wide variety of functional groups and branching points in lignin complicates product selectivity, as many reaction pathways can occur sequentially or in parallel. This makes reaction-condition modulation to produce a single desired product or product class challenging. Oxidative routes may produce aldehydes, acids, and phenolics simultaneously, thereby requiring advanced separation and purification steps that impact scalability. The complexity and heterogeneity of lignin pose significant challenges for catalyst design. Besides maintaining high catalytic activity and stability, minimizing undesirable reactions, including condensation and repolymerization, during lignin depolymerization is critical for ensuring the maximum yield of the desired product. To overcome these challenges, several approaches, including catalytic depolymerization, oxidative degradation, and hydrothermal liquefaction, which convert lignin into relatively reactive smaller fragments that can be transformed into valuable chemicals and materials have been explored. Finally, process integration at the industrial scale remains an obstacle. Lignin valorization must be harmonized with carbohydrate processing in biorefineries to ensure economic feasibility. At present, lignin is often treated as waste and few commercial plants are optimized to handle its isolation, purification, and conversion in a dedicated stream. Overcoming this limitation will require the co-design of technologies and supply chains that prioritize lignin as a primary product rather than a byproduct. Thus, as detailed above, efficient and sustainable lignin valorization remains significantly challenging to date. 3 Prospective approaches for the oxidative fractionation of lignin Oxidative fractionation for lignin valorization requires the optimization of solvent systems, catalysts, and oxidants designed to promote higher conversion rates and selective product formation. Solvent systems critically underpin solubilizing the lignin and facilitating its catalytic interactions, and catalysts are key contributors toward selective lignin oxidation. Oxidants show varying degrees of reactivity, exhibiting a balance between oxidative strength and product selectivity [14]. 3.1 Solvents used in the oxidation fractionation of lignin The solvent system plays a pivotal role in ensuring the efficient oxidative fractionation of lignin. The solvent should be environmentally benign, economically viable, and capable of facilitating the efficient mass transfer of reactants and products. Various solvents, including water, methanol, ethanol, and acetone, can be used for lignin oxidative fractionation processes [5,15–17]. Frequently used solvents include alcohols, particularly methanol, ethanol, and isopropanol, which also function as reagents that stabilize the reaction intermediates [18]. Lignocellulosic biomass fractionation typically requires solvent systems that can selectively break the complex matrices of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin. The distinct influences of different solvent types on product distribution and reaction efficiency have been investigated in several studies. Alcohols (such as methanol and ethanol) generally promote the formation of monophenolic compounds due to their ability to solubilize lignin and suppress condensation. Generally, alcoholic solvents can cleave the ester and ether linkages within lignin while improving its solubility. These solvents facilitate the cleavage of β–O–4 linkages, releasing lignin monomers. Acetone and dioxane, functioning as aprotic co-solvents, aid in delignification and minimize re-polymerization but require catalyst compatibility for optimal activity. Acetone, which is frequently used as a co-solvent, aids in the solubilization of lignin and its derivatives while maintaining a low-polarity environment. Dioxane and tetrahydrofuran are used because of their capacity to solubilize lignin and minimize the formation of polymerization by-products [15,16]. Water, a non-toxic and economical solvent, is often used alongside organic solvents or under subcritical and supercritical conditions to improve the solubility and reactivity of lignin. Water enhances hydrolysis and delignification but may result in broader product distributions that include carboxylic acids. Although water-based fractionation processes may be effective in removing hemicellulose, the intrinsic insolubility of lignin in water often limits its recovery and valorization [18]. However, subcritical water can disrupt hydrogen bonding within the lignocellulosic matrix, increasing its solvent accessibility; this facilitates the partial solubilization of lignin and enables its recovery. Besides showing a dual purpose in the depolymerization reaction (i.e., maintaining the alkalinity of the reaction medium and promoting lignin solubility), water and alcohol mixtures suppress demethoxylation during depolymerization [16]. In binary systems such as ethanol–water or isopropanol–water, synergistic effects have been observed—where water enhances reactivity while alcohol stabilizes intermediates. Studies with solvent mixtures containing various alcohol to water ratios (such as 8:2 and 9.5:0.5) indicate that the addition of water (even minimal) into the solvent system significantly expedites the lignin fractionation process by improving β–O–4 bond cleavage with suppressing condensation pathways [19]. Among emerging green solvents, ionic liquids (ILs) and deep eutectic solvents (DES) are promising solvents that stand out for their ability to expedite lignocellulosic biomass fractionation. These solvents adversely affect the interaction between lignin and carbohydrates by selectively dissolving lignin while retaining the structural integrity of cellulose. ILs such as 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium acetate efficiently cleave the hydrogen bonds in cellulose and lignin. Notably, DES, comprising renewable and biodegradable materials, show similar efficiency in lignin extraction and depolymerization as ILs, thereby providing a relatively green alternative for lignin depolymerization [20,21]. Thus, solvent-solution selection should be based on balancing lignin solubilization, the bond cleavage efficiency, environmental effect, and catalyst system compatibility as it influences the efficiency of lignin depolymerization significantly, rendering it a crucial factor in the design of oxidative methods for lignin valorization. 3.2 Types of metal catalyst The catalyst design significantly affects the efficiency of lignin depolymerization. Acid, base, metal, and non-metal catalysts are frequently used in oxidative fractionation. Each catalyst deconstructs the lignin structure through a different reaction pathway; therefore, catalyst design is an important factor controlling the desired product yield. Catalytic metals used in oxidative lignin depolymerization can be broadly classified into two categories: noble metals (such as Pt, Pd, Ru, and Rh) and non-noble or base metals (such as Cu, Co, Mn, and Fe). Noble metals generally demonstrate excellent catalytic activity and selectivity due to their ability to facilitate redox transformations with high stability. For instance, Pt- and Pd-based catalysts supported on CeO2 or TiO2 have shown high selectivity towards aldehydes and carboxylic acids, with minimal by-product formation [22,23]. Although noble metals are highly effective in catalyzing intermolecular bond cleavage in lignin, their high cost has prompted the development of highly efficient low-cost catalysts by incorporating secondary metals into noble metals. In contrast, non-noble metals such as Cu, Co, Mn, and Fe offer cost-effective alternatives with promising redox properties. These metals often favor the formation of phenolic compounds and short-chain carboxylic acids. For instance, Cu-based catalysts (such as CuO and Cu/Zeolite) efficiently promote β–O–4 bond cleavage, yielding syringol, guaiacol, and vanillin derivatives, while Co- and Mn-based systems can enhance vanillin and syringaldehyde selectivity under mild oxidative conditions. Considerable attention has been given to the catalytic conversion of lignin to phenolics with heterogeneous catalysts containing Co, Cu, and Mn [11] along with oxidative lignin fractionation with transition metal catalysts, such as Co–Mo, Co–CeO2, FeCl3, CuCl2, and Mn–Mo, as alternatives to noble metals. A comparative analysis of the catalyst performances summarized in Table 1 reveals that non-noble bimetallic systems such as Co–Cu/Zeolite HY and Cu–Mn/γ-A2O3 show significantly higher product yields than noble metal systems such as Pd/CeO2 or Pt/TiO2, which tend to offer lower yields (∼9 %) but better selectivity for aldehydes and carboxylic acids. This indicates a trade-off between activity and selectivity across catalyst types. Single-component systems such as CuCl2 and Co–Mn–O show limited performance (6–9 % yield), whereas their bimetallic counterparts show improved efficiency and recyclability. The catalytic performance of these systems is closely related to the nature of their active centers. Noble metal catalysts such as Pd/CeO2 and Pt/TiO2 rely on highly dispersed metallic sites interfaced with reducible oxide supports. These metal–support interactions provide oxygen vacancies and Lewis acidic sites that facilitate C–O bond cleavage, stabilize reactive oxygen, and interact with intermediates, promoting oxidative dehydrogenation and selective aldehyde formation [23,24]. In contrast, base metals such as Cu2+ and Mn3+ exhibit redox flexibility (Cu2+/Cu+, Mn3+/Mn2+), which is critical for generating reactive oxygen species and driving radical-based oxidation. These redox pairs facilitate electron transfer processes necessary for ether (β–O–4) and C–C bond cleavage. Bimetallic systems, such as Co–Cu or Cu–Mn, display synergistic redox behavior that enhances turnover rates and catalytic stability. For example, in Co–Cu systems, Co3+ functions as the primary oxidizing species for lignin fragments, while Cu2+ regenerates Co2+, maintaining continuous redox cycling. This interplay reduces catalyst deactivation and improves selectivity. Similarly, Cu–Mn combinations utilize dual redox mechanisms for the efficient activation of oxidants such as H2O2 or O2. Recent advances in bimetallic systems, such as Co–Cu or Cu–Mn combinations, demonstrate synergistic redox cycles—improving catalyst longevity, recyclability, and the selective oxidation of lignin side chains [24,25]. These dual systems bridge the gap between activity and affordability, with examples showing high yields of aromatic aldehydes and acids at moderate temperatures. Support materials also play a critical role. Reducible oxides such as CeO2 and TiO2 enhance oxygen transfer and electron mobility, while porous supports such as Zeolite HY and γ-Al2O3 stabilize the metal particles, improve dispersion, and suppress side reactions. These supports often introduce Brønsted or Lewis acid sites into the system, which promote lignin fragmentation and product stabilization. 3.3 Types of catalyst supports Various catalyst supports with unique characteristics, benefits, and drawbacks have been used in the oxidative fractionation of lignin. Although alumina exhibits high thermal stability, a large surface area, and a well-ordered porous structure, regulating the hydrolysis rate of aluminum precursors is challenging [34]. Silica is characterized by its abundance and capacity to create extensive networks, which contribute toward its high efficiency, selectivity, and mechanical strength; however, silica exhibits low compatibility and aggregation [35]. Zeolites exhibit excellent thermal stability and shape selectivity, and its acidic sites show high potential for phenolic monomer production [25]; nonetheless, they exhibit a tendency to irreversibly adsorb secondary products and show limited applicability in continuous processes [35]. Zeolite based supports (including HY and ZSM-5) promote product selectivity due to their Brønsted and Lewis acidity, enabling the breakdown of β–O–4 linkages and enhancing the yield of guaiacol- and syringol-type products. Their microporous structure can, however, hinder mass transfer, especially for bulky lignin fragments, limiting large-scale performance unless modified through desilication or dealumination. Alumina (Al2O3) supports, on the other hand, offer strong interaction with metal oxides and excellent thermal stability, making them effective for oxidation reactions that require elevated temperatures [36]. However, acidic alumina can promote undesired condensation reactions, reducing phenolic yields [37]. Carbon-based supports show a porous structure, high surface area, and excellent electrical and thermal conductivities, thereby exhibiting high mechanical strength and inertness. These support materials (including activated carbon, carbon nanotubes, and biochar) often facilitate the high dispersion of metal particles, leading to improved redox performance. Additionally, their inert nature minimizes side reactions, allowing the selective production of aldehydes and monophenolics. However, carbon supports may undergo metal leaching and are difficult to recover post-reaction in slurry systems. Additionally, the separation of catalysts with carbon-based supports after reaction completion is challenging [27,35]. Metal oxide supports, such as TiO2 and CeO2, provide high oxygen mobility and redox capability, in particular, CeO2-supported catalysts have shown notable efficiency in converting lignin to aldehydes and acids due to their ability to shuttle oxygen species effectively. They also suppress recondensation by stabilizing radical intermediates [22,23]. Thus, for the efficient oxidative fractionation of lignin, the choice of support must be aligned with the desired product profile, catalyst stability, and scalability requirements. Tailoring support acidity, porosity, and interaction with metal species is vital for tuning selectivity and improving catalytic performance in lignin valorization. 3.4 Different oxidants Oxidants pointedly affect the pathway, efficiency, and product selectivity of lignin oxidative-fractionation reactions. Molecular oxygen (O2) or oxygen gas (air) is widely used as an oxidant because of its cost-effectiveness and environmental safety, and is frequently used under catalytic conditions to produce reactive oxygen species. However, exposure to O2 can result in the overoxidation of the functional groups in lignin, leading to the formation of undesired products [8]. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), which enables the facile production of hydroxyl radicals and readily undergoes reduction to form water and oxygen during oxidation, is another oxidant that is widely used in organic reactions [27]. Hydrogen peroxide decomposition in the presence of catalysts, such as transition metal ions (including Fe2+ and Fe3+), results in the production of highly reactive hydroxyl radicals (•OH) that attack aromatic rings and cleave C–C and C–O bonds, promoting lignin depolymerization [7]. Ozone (O3) is another strong oxidizing agent that reacts with lignin via electrophilic addition and radical mechanisms. The selective attack of double bonds in the aromatic structure in lignin results in bond cleavage and the formation of carboxylic acids and aldehydes [38]. The high reactivity of ozone enables rapid oxidation; however, avoiding overoxidation is critical. Although nitrobenzene and several other oxidants that influence the reaction pathway, efficiency, and product distribution are also considered suitable for lignin oxidation [39], their application is limited owing to high toxicity, environmental risks, and safety hazards. Alternative oxidizing agents, such as peracetic acid and sodium periodate, have been recently explored for their selectivity in the oxidation of lignin side chains and aromatic structures. Peracetic acid generates reactive peroxyl radicals, which facilitate the selective breakdown of the ether bonds in lignin, and sodium periodate oxidizes the vicinal diols in lignin, resulting in the formation of carbonyl groups, and modifies aromatic rings [40]. Studies have also investigated the applicability of potassium permanganate and potassium dichromate in lignin oxidation; although historically significant, these oxidants are less favored because of environmental concerns [41]. Thus, the choice of oxidant is contingent on the intended products, reaction parameters, and eco-friendliness of lignin oxidation. 4 Mechanisms of the oxidative fractionation and depolymerization of lignin Oxidative fractionation and depolymerization lead to the breakdown of the polymeric structure of lignin into small molecules via an oxidation reaction. Fractionation is a promising method for the selective separation of lignin from lignocellulosic materials [5,9,42], and depolymerization disrupts the intermolecular bonding in lignin macromolecules. The mechanisms of oxidative fractionation and depolymerization mainly involve the cleavage of ether bonds, such as β-aryl etheric linkages, which represent the most prevalent and reactive bonds in lignin [8]. Oxidants produce reactive oxygen species that attack the bonds between the aromatic rings and side chains in lignin. This process typically involves the oxidation of hydroxyl groups to form ketones or carboxylic acids and the cleavage of interunit linkages. Catalysts such as metal-based systems (including Pt, Pd, Cu, Mn, and Co) facilitate selective bond cleavage, minimize over-oxidation, and increase the reaction efficiency. Moreover, the synergistic effects of oxidative fractionation and depolymerization allow simultaneous separation and conversion, maximizing efficiency, reducing process complexity, and enabling better control of product selectivity [43,44]. The reaction occurs via radical or ionic pathways and is influenced by the reaction temperature and oxidant, enabling the selective formation of phenolic monomers, aldehydes, or carboxylic acids. Understanding the mechanisms of oxidative fractionation and depolymerization is essential for developing effective methods to control the reaction pathways to generate the desired compounds. Studies have extensively investigated the oxidation of aromatic monomers to understand the reactivity of the functional groups in lignin, including the hydroxyl, methoxy, carbonyl, and carboxyl groups, as well as their transformation into different compounds such as phenolics, aldehydes, and carboxylic acids. Recent research has focused on the formation of certain lignin-associated aromatic monomers, such as apocynol and different alcohols, after the oxidation of the OH functional group, and the subsequent production of the corresponding carboxylic acids. Depolymerization generally occurs through the mechanism of oxidation reactions, wherein the oxidant (i.e., oxygen) promotes the cleavage of ether bonds, particularly the β−O − 4 linkage. Subsequently, the lignin monomers and dimers are transformed into phenolic compounds. The application of catalysts, especially Co-supported Ca catalysts, significantly improves the efficiency of lignin depolymerization by selectively breaking ether bonds, thereby optimizing the production of valuable compounds such as vanillin [3]. Apocynol has been used as a model compound to investigate the mechanism of oxidative solvolysis with the SBA-15 and Co (salen)/SBA-15 catalysts using H2O2 as the oxidant. The principal oxidation pathways are shown in Fig. 2 . Different products, namely, acetovanillone, vanillin, and 2-methoxybenzoquinone, are formed in different steps of the reaction initiated by the oxidation of the side-chain hydroxyl group into the ketone functional group. Subsequently, the methyl group is oxidized to an aldehyde. In the final step, the phenolic group is oxidized and the p-alkyl side chain undergoes degradation [38,45]. The oxidation of 2-phenoxyethanol with vanadium complexes yields phenol, formic acid, and several minor products, underscoring the impact of catalyst design and reaction conditions in determining the mechanism of oxidation reactions [46]. The oxidation of veratryl alcohol with a nanostructured spinel Co3O4 catalyst yields 85 % veratryl aldehyde. The reaction is initiated by the adsorption of veratryl alcohol on the catalyst, which leads to the formation of an intermediate compound owing to Co (III)–hydroxyl group interactions. Subsequently, the reductive elimination of veratryl aldehyde results in the formation of Co (II). Finally, Co (II) is re-oxidized to Co (III), and veratryl aldehyde is oxidized to veratric acid. This catalytic cycle is shown in Fig. 3 [14]. A study reports the mechanism of the oxidative depolymerization of kraft lignin with mixed Cu/Mn oxides and H2O2 [31]. The catalysts expedite the breakage of the ether links in lignin, producing vanillin, syringaldehyde, vanillic acid, syringic acid, acetovanillone, and 4-hydroxybenzaldehyde as the major aromatic compounds. The highest vanillin yield (6.8 %) occurs at 150 °C, as elevated temperatures result in the excessive oxidation of organic acids. The excellent catalytic activity under these conditions can be ascribed to the good redox characteristics and facile oxygen mobility of the catalysts, as validated by oxygen temperature-programmed desorption experiments. A mechanism proposed for vanillin production from an intermediate comprising the lignin-containing alcohol of the G-unit (coniferyl) is shown in Fig. 4 . H2O2 is adsorbed onto active Cu–Mn sites and decomposed into O2, which is converted into surface oxygen species at the oxygen vacancies, leading to the formation of a manganese–copper oxide complex (Mn3+–O–Cu2+). Subsequently, coniferyl alcohol is oxidized to vanillin by these surface oxygen species. Notably, depending on the active Cu content of the catalyst, vanillin can be oxidized further (to vanillic acid). Biomass may require pretreatment before oxidative fractionation; however, pretreatment results in a lower yield of lignin monomers [5]. The different pretreatment methods reported to date are compared in Fig. 5 . On using a Co–N–C catalyst and O2 with acetone as the reaction medium, lignin can be effectively separated from carbohydrates during the conversion of lignin into valuable aromatic compounds. The Co–N–C catalyst promotes lignin oxidation, breaking down its complex structure into phenolic monomers, aldehydes, and carboxylic acids with a reported yield of ∼15 wt %. Additionally, it stabilizes these phenolic monomers, reduces their degradation, preserves their yield, and controls the reactive radical species in the system to prevent undesired side reactions. The Co–N–C catalyst enables the reaction to occur under non-alkaline conditions, protecting the cellulose integrity and ensuring its recovery as a high-quality solid fraction. This innovative approach efficiently balances lignin depolymerization and carbohydrate preservation, offering an advanced alternative to traditional biomass pretreatment methods. The pretreatment process reduces product yields, whereas bypassing separation significantly increases aromatic monomer yields [4]. The oxidative catalytic fractionation (OCF) strategy shown in Fig. 6(a) enables the direct conversion of the lignin in lignocellulosic biomass into aromatic monomers, such as vanillin and methyl vanillate, in yields of 22.49 %, while preserving the cellulose structure. In the isolated lignin depolymerization technique shown in Fig. 6(b), pretreatment alters the inherent structure of lignin, resulting in the formation of resistant linkages that hinder depolymerization. Polyoxometalates (POMs) are effective catalysts for OCF; the redox characteristics of POMs facilitate lignin oxidation and inhibit undesirable condensation processes, enabling the selective transformation of lignin into useful monomers under mild conditions while preserving cellulose integrity, thereby providing an efficient and environmentally sustainable method for biomass valorization. Lignin separation and depolymerization occur in a single process in the one-pot oxidative method [43]. As shown in Fig. 7 , the initial phase involves lignin extraction from the lignocellulosic matrix with a dilute POM catalyst in a methanol–water mixture at 100 °C. This process stabilizes the reactive α-OH groups of lignin, inhibiting condensation and facilitating a high output of lignin-derived compounds. In the second phase, the lignin solution is heated to 140 °C under identical solvent conditions, facilitating the breaking of linkages within the lignin structure. This process produces small lignin fragments and a significant fraction of aromatic monomers with minimal recondensation. POMs function as effective oxidizing catalysts, cleaving lignin–carbohydrate linkages and promoting lignin solubilization and depolymerization into aromatic monomers such as vanillin and syringaldehyde. Moreover, their redox characteristics facilitate regeneration and ensure prolonged catalytic efficiency. On applying POM catalysts in a methanol–water system to eucalyptus powder [2], lignin is selectively destroyed and cellulose is retained, which can be converted to lignocellulose nanofibrils. Compared with pure water, the methanol–water system facilitates lignin breakdown and inhibits condensation processes, significantly improving aromatic monomer yields. The reaction occurs under mild conditions (140 °C, 1 h), and the products can be isolated post-reaction by filtering cellulose-rich WIS and removing lignin-derived chemicals with dichloromethane (Fig. 8 ). Therefore, this oxidative catalytic fractionation method markedly improved lignin extraction and its transformation into useful compounds, presenting a viable option for lignin valorization in biorefineries. Co/Zeolite HY and Cu/Zeolite HY catalysts have also been utilized in the simultaneous fractionation and depolymerization of lignin [27], yielding the efficient generation of phenolic derivatives and aldehydes as primary compounds and carboxylic acids as secondary products. The proposed reaction mechanism shown in Fig. 9 highlights the role of metal catalysts in promoting the oxidation reaction. The mechanism involves a dynamic equilibrium involving lattice oxygen species on the catalyst surface, which facilitates the incorporation of hydroxyl (OH) groups, enabling oxidative dehydrogenation, finally leading to aldehyde formation [48,49]. Some aldehydes are subsequently transformed into the corresponding carboxylic acids. Furthermore, some carboxylic acids undergo decarboxylation during this process, yielding phenolic compounds [50]. The proposed mechanism of a bimetallic Co–Cu/Zeolite HY catalyst that shows a higher yield than a single metal catalyst [25] is shown in Fig. 10 . The synergistic oxidation mechanism is similar to the catalytic cycle of the Wacker process in which Co primarily facilitates lignin oxidation and induces C–O bond cleavage. During this process, Co3+ is reduced to Co2+, while Cu2+ facilitates the re-oxidation of Co2+ to Co3+, maintaining the redox cycle. The redox coupling between Co3+/Co2+ and Cu2+/Cu+ is crucial for sustaining robust activity in the oxidative conversion of lignin. Selective oxidation in lignin valorization can be finely tuned by modulating the catalyst structure and reaction conditions. For example, controlling the particle size and dispersion of metal catalysts enhances the active-site accessibility. Acidic supports (such as ZSM-5 and HY) promote β–O–4 cleavage, while CeO2-based catalysts stabilize radical intermediates and suppress over-oxidation. Operating under controlled temperatures (100–140 °C), oxygen pressures, and solvent polarity (such as methanol–water vs. acetone) directs the reaction toward specific products. Phenol production is favored under reductive conditions, while aldehydes and acids are produced under oxidative regimes. Therefore, the catalyst microstructure and electronic properties, in conjunction with tailored solvent–oxidant systems, enable the targeted synthesis of vanillin, syringaldehyde, guaiacol, and benzoic acids. Future studies should aim to couple in-situ spectroscopic tools with product analysis to clearly resolve the transient intermediates involved in oxidative lignin depolymerization. A major hindrance in the depolymerization of lignin bonds is the re-polymerization of reactive intermediates, which can significantly reduce the yield and selectivity of the reaction. During oxidative bond cleavage, intermediates such as phenoxy radicals, quinones, and unstable carbocations are generated. These intermediates are likely to self-condense or combine with leftover lignin chains, forming new C–C or C–O bonds, which generates oligomers with greater molecular weights than lignin, stable char, or condensed lignin residues. This type of repolymerization is frequently observed under high temperature and strong acid conditions because radical recombination and electrophilic substitution pathways are more common. Uncontrolled radical coupling processes generate β–5 and 5–5 links [51,52]. Several strategies exist for mitigating these side reactions. Solvent solutions, including methanol, ethanol, and acetone, can stabilize reactive intermediates through hydrogen-bond formation or solvation effects, which prevent condensation [51,53]. Catalyst supports such as CeO2 and TiO2 contribute toward hindering radicals or changing the redox balance to stabilize monomers. Also, using redox-active co-catalysts and in-situ hydrogen donors such alcohols or formic acid can prevent re-polymerization. Future catalyst design should include features that not only enable specific bond breakage but also promote the stabilization or elimination of reactive intermediates to facilitate efficient depolymerization and improve the purity of the product. 5 Current challenges and future directions Currently, the utilization of lignin in lignocellulosic biomass is an important area of research owing to the increasing demand for renewable and sustainable resources. One promising approach to unlock the potential of this abundant biomass is the oxidative fractionation and depolymerization of lignin in a single process. However, several challenges remain unaddressed to date. Currently, most research on the catalytic conversion of lignin focuses on the use of model compounds, resulting in an insufficient understanding of the processes and mechanisms of the oxidation of real lignin. Furthermore, the structure and composition of lignin vary significantly with the raw material and extraction methods used, making lignin conversion complex. Moreover, ensuring high selectivity in product distribution is challenging because competing reaction pathways make the controlled formation of specific compounds, including phenols, aldehydes, and carboxylic acids, difficult. Additionally, the cost-effectiveness of the process is a significant concern, particularly in terms of catalyst stability and recyclability. Therefore, despite significant research efforts, the efficient conversion of lignin into valuable chemicals remains a formidable challenge. Traditional methods, such as thermal and catalytic depolymerization, often yield complex product mixtures and require high energy input. To overcome these limitations, several targeted strategies can be adopted to advance lignin depolymerization research. First, tandem catalysis—where oxidative and hydrogenolytic steps occur sequentially or in a one-pot setup—can improve both cleavage efficiency and product stabilization. Dual-functional catalysts, capable of both bond scission and hydrogen donation, may reduce intermediate condensation and enhance monomer yields. Second, machine-learning-guided catalyst design can accelerate the discovery of efficient and cost-effective systems by screening compositional and structural variables (including metal loading, support acidity, and redox potential) using predictive models. Third, in-situ spectroscopic techniques can be integrated into depolymerization systems to monitor reaction intermediates in real time, enabling rational reaction control and minimizing over oxidation. Fourth, solvent engineering—particularly the use of tunable DES or supercritical CO2 mixtures—offers a promising route to optimize lignin solubilization while preserving labile intermediates. Lastly, the development of bio-derived, recyclable catalyst supports (including hydrochar and alginate composites) could reduce environmental impacts while maintaining high catalytic efficiency. To improve the economic viability of the process further, integrating lignin valorization into existing biorefinery infrastructure, coupled with heat integration, could reduce operational costs. The development of cost-effective, recyclable, and stable catalysts that can operate under mild reaction conditions is crucial for the large-scale production of biofuels and other value-added chemicals via lignin depolymerization. Currently, most lignin is burned for power production, and the energy-intensive nature of water removal from wet lignin streams limits its value to less than $50 per dry ton [54,55]. Converting lignin into advanced liquid fuels, such as jet fuel, holds greater economic promise; it could enhance the overall profitability of biorefineries while supporting renewable energy goals [13,56]. There is significant market demand for benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX) and phenols; the BTX demand exceeds 100 million tons annually and averages $1200 per ton, making this market worth $100 billion [6,57]. These cost benefits highlight the significant commercial potential of efficient lignin valorization. In addition to certain economic advantages, the catalysts used in lignin-based processes often exhibit excellent stability and reusability, enhancing the overall cost efficiency of the processes by reducing the need for frequent catalyst replacement. Collectively, these factors highlight the viability of lignin as a sustainable feedstock that offers economic and operational advantages. However, several challenges, such as high catalyst cost, catalyst deactivation due to coking, and the need for precise reaction conditions, persist. To address these issues, low-cost transition metal catalysts supported on robust frameworks and engineered for resistance to coking and leaching should be explored. Improving reactor systems with continuous monitoring may enable better control over reaction pathways and scalability. Innovative strategies, such as the development of low-cost robust catalytic systems, exhibit high potential to overcome these limitations. For industrial implementation, a roadmap addressing the technical, economic, and environmental aspects of lignin processing is required. This may involve the integration of multiple technologies, the optimization of the separation and purification steps, and the exploration of innovative business models that make the process economically viable. The single-pot oxidative fractionation and depolymerization of lignin can be used to extract aromatic chemicals, such as vanillin and syringaldehyde, from lignin while conserving the carbohydrate fractions for industrial use. Collaborative frameworks among academia, industry, and policy institutions will also be essential in enabling the development of standardized lignin feedstocks and scalable, regulation-compliant processes. 6 Conclusions The oxidative fractionation and depolymerization of lignin with metal catalysts are more efficient and sustainable than traditional methods of lignin processing, and enable the selective production of target phenolic compounds, thereby improving the overall valorization process. Through the use of tailored solvents, efficient metal catalysts, and selective oxidants, oxidative fractionation and depolymerization enable the selective cleavage of the complex structure of lignin, maximizing the yield of desired products. This review advances the existing body of literature by highlighting practical solvent–catalyst–oxidant combinations tailored for specific lignin feedstocks as well as recent developments in bimetallic and multifunctional catalytic systems. By comparing support types and their influence on product yield and selectivity, this review provides insight for rational catalyst design. The development of stable and recyclable catalysts is expected to enhance the economic and environmental sustainability of lignin processing. Moreover, the integration of oxidative fractionation and depolymerization into a single-pot process can simplify operation, reduce energy consumption, and minimize waste generation. Moving forward, a deeper mechanistic understanding of solvent–substrate–catalyst interactions and scale-up studies using real biomass feedstocks are essential for commercial deployment. Therefore, as summarized in this paper, oxidative fractionation and depolymerization processing enable the optimal utilization of lignin as a valuable resource for a circular bioeconomy that can contribute toward the development of a sustainable future. This review aims to function as a comprehensive resource for future studies investigating commercially viable and efficient strategies for lignin processing. coredata.dc:description: Lignin, a complex phenolic biopolymer, is currently an inadequately utilized component of lignocellulosic biomass because the aromatic structure and high chemical stability of lignin make its extraction from biomass challenging. Oxidative fractionation and depolymerization, particularly with the aid of metal catalysts, holds significant potential for transforming lignin into high-value chemicals, including phenolics, aldehydes, and carboxylic acids. This review offers a comprehensive overview of recent progress in the oxidative valorization of lignin, focusing on proposed catalytic systems, solvent selection, the oxidant efficiency, and depolymerization mechanisms. This paper uniquely adopts a comparative approach, highlighting the influence of solvent polarity and reactivity, catalyst metal type, and support materials on product distribution. Besides critically analyzing the role of catalysts, catalyst supports, and reaction conditions in enhancing the selectivity and yield of target products, integrated approaches, such as one-pot catalytic processes and solvent-modulated fractionation techniques, which can improve the efficiency and economic feasibility of lignin processing are discussed in this review. Moreover, this review emphasizes recent advances in redox-active catalyst design in solvent system engineering. Despite significant progress, certain challenges, such as poor catalyst stability, process scalability, and selectivity for the desired products, persist in lignin extraction. To address these issues, future research should prioritize advanced catalytic models, optimized processes, and the development of environmentally benign and cost-effective technologies that can unlock the potential of lignin as a sustainable feedstock for the production of bio-based chemicals.
